SlideShow.Title: Slide show: Proper lifting techniques
SlideShow.Abstract: Want to prevent back pain? Practice proper lifting techniques.

Slide.Caption:
Before you lift a heavy object, think through your task. Decide where you're going to place the object and how you'll get it there. If an object is too heavy to lift safely, find someone to help you or make several trips carrying lighter weight.

When lifting an object from the floor, stand as close to the object as possible. Then kneel, resting one knee on the floor. Don't lift from a standing position with your waist bent or your knees locked.
Slide.Title: Start in a safe position
Slide.ImageAltText: Photo of man kneeling to lift a box

Slide.Caption: With one knee resting on the floor, tighten your core muscles — including the muscles in your abdomen, back and pelvis — and lift the object between your legs. Maintain the natural curve in your lower back, and don't hold your breath. Be careful to hold the object close to your body. Rest the object on your knee as you prepare to stand.
Slide.Title: Maintain the natural curve in your lower back
Slide.ImageAltText: Photo of man lifting box to his knee

Slide.Caption: As you stand, maintain the natural curve in your lower back and keep your core muscles tight. Use your leg muscles — not your back — to lift the object.
Slide.Title: Use your legs
Slide.ImageAltText: Photo of man standing as he finishes lifting a box

Slide.Caption: As another option, squat rather than kneel to lift an object from the floor. Stand as close to the object as possible, positioning it between your knees as you squat. Keep your feet parallel, as shown here, or stagger one foot ahead of the other. It might help to tilt one edge of the box up to ensure a firm hold.
Slide.Title: Squatting instead of kneeling
Slide.ImageAltText: Photo of man squatting as he begins to lift a box

Slide.Caption: As you stand, be careful to hold the object close to your body. Maintain the natural curve in your lower back, and keep your core muscles tight. Use your leg muscles — not your back — to lift the object.
Slide.Title: Let your legs do the work
Slide.ImageAltText: Photo of man lifting from a squat

Slide.Caption: When you're standing and ready to move, continue holding the object close to your body to decrease the strain on your lower back. Keep your core muscles tight. Turn by pivoting your feet, not your back.
Slide.Title: Avoid twisting
Slide.ImageAltText: Photo of man holding a box
